Award.AwardTitle: Planning Meeting for a US-Italy Coastal Antarctic Time Series
Award.AbstractNarration:
This international planning grant will enable researchers from the USA to collaborate with Italian oceanographers in planning and developing a long term time series program at the Italian Base in Terra Nova Bay, Antarctica. The long term goal involves observing the effects of climate change on the biogeochemical cycling of carbon and nutrients in the western Ross Sea, an important region of Antarctic Bottom Water formation. The goals of the planning grant include: (1) determining the current state of US-Italian knowledge in the Ross Sea; (2) prioritizing the most important scientific issues to be addressed in future collaborations; (3) developing a plan for both short term and long term funding of collaborative activities; and (4) planning logistical operations by both nations. The proposed western Ross Sea time series program will serve as both an environmental sentinel and a natural laboratory to understand the impacts of climate change.

The planning visit, and future international collaborations, will facilitate the development of the next generation of scientists in Antarctica. Italian post-doctoral and graduate students, as well as junior US researchers, will participate in the planning meeting. A long term study of the western Ross Sea will enable new investigators to be involved in all aspects of planning and testing hypotheses regarding the impacts of climate change on a coastal Antarctic ecosystem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A planning meeting was convened to discuss the possible formation of a long term time series station and program in the western Ross Sea at Terra Nova Bay (TNB), Antarctica that would leverage the logistical resources and scientific expertise of the Italian and US Antarctic research programs. The scientific justification for such a program was recently elucidated in the Southern Ocean Scoping workshop entitled “A US Southern Ocean Carbon, Ecosystems and Biogeochemistry Science Plan” that was held at Princeton University in June 2009 (http://www.whoi.edu/cms/files/SOWorkshop_Report_Final_61243.pdf). In brief, the scientific consensus reached at that meeting emphasized the relative importance of understanding the physics, biogeochemistry and ecosystem functioning of the Southern Ocean with respect to the Earth’s climate system. Due to the high biological productivity in Antarctic coastal waters these regions of Antarctic bottom water formation represent important sites for carbon sequestration. Our ability to discern future ecosystem changes in the Southern Ocean as a function of both anthropogenic and natural climate variability is dependent upon establishing a long-term time series program in the western Ross Sea, similar to the LTER site on the western Antarctic Peninsula. The goal of this planning meeting was to initiate scientific, programmatic, and logistical discussions to formulate the foundation for developing such a program.

 

Twenty scientists (including 4 from the US) and a program officer from the Italian Research Funding Agency (PNRA) convened to discuss the possible collaboration. In brief, it was decided that an international collaboration between the two countries would be mutually beneficial. A tentative research plan was formulated that included determining several sites to deploy various moorings in the western Ross Sea to collect oceanographic data. In addition, a discussion and plan for potential funding opportunities between the two countries was outlined.  At that time, it was decided that the Italian researchers would submit a proposal to PNRA and the US scientists would submit a grant proposal to NSF-PIRE (Partnership in International Research and Education) program (proposal deadline of fall 2011). Recently, however, we have learned that the PIRE program has changed its focus to one that emphasizes sustainability. As a result, a change in our proposal plans was necessitated and we are currently working toward submitting a research proposal based on our planning meeting scientific proceedings to the NSF-AISS program (Antarctic Integrated System Science) with a deadline of June 2012. We have also been in contact with Drs. Kang and Yim from the Korea Polar Research Institute about their possible involvement with our program. Korean researchers are extremely interested in collaborating as their country has a new icebreaker (RV/IB Araon) that is operating in Antarctic coastal waters and more importantly a new research station being built in Terra Nova Bay, Antarctica that will open in 2014.  The proximity of the Korean base to the Italian base in Terra Nova Bay as well as logistical support from McMurdo Station will provide a great opportunity for developing an international program to begin a long term study on changing oceanic conditions and its effects on the biology and biogeochemistry of the western Ross Sea ecosystem, especially with regards to their impacts on the global carbon cycle.
